displayed_text: Healthcare Professional: Oh! Doctor: -making his little Dunkin Donuts box- Healthcare Professional: Mhm. Doctor: -and I was like, “this is not what I have to do for school projects and stuff. Family Member: I think it was looked pretty good. Healthcare Professional: Just let me know when you’re done and I’ll come turn it off. Doctor: Okay, great. Thank you. Okay. Patient: Alrighty. Doctor: Okay. All right. So first we have to go over results. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So you have the CAT scan- Patient: Mhm.

Patient: Are you gonna give me the sixty OxyContin? Doctor: Yeah I gave you. One is sixty and then the Percocet is a… Patient: One hundred twenty? Doctor: One hundred twenty. Patient: Okay, last time you gave me OxyContin, you gave me one hundred twenty. Doctor: I know because that was the short acting. That’s what I’m telling you. The short acting OxyContin you had one hundred twenty. This is the long acting. Healthcare Professional: This is the one you take in the morning and at night. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So - that’s why I said if I give you the Percocet it’s going to lower your dose of OxyContin. Patient: Okay, okay. Doctor: But if that works for you I’m good with that. Patient: Okay.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.4 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::4 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::strongly agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.strongly disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.::: strongly disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.::: strongly disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.::: strongly disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.strongly disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers::: strongly disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.strongly disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind::: strongly disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed
Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …and we’re gonna go over just the research part of it, so this is literally bio-specimen acquiring study which means when after we biopsy we’re gonna take several passes more to get extra stuff and that’s the end. And we won’t do it – Patient: Take the whole - Doctor: Take the whole thing out! (laughs) Patient: No, take the whole damn thing out. Patient: Take it all! Doctor: I know. The needle is yeh big and this thing is still yeh big so uh we would have to do a lot of passes. Patient: da Vinci procedure, da Vinci procedure. Doctor: Look at you. Get you on the table just like that. (laughs) Patient: da Vinci procedure (makes whistle noise) Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Snip, snip, snip, bzzz. (makes various noises) Doctor: See that. You’re

Patient: This will be done here? Doctor: Those – a lot of those intense monitoring and everything has to be done downtown. Family Member: But is it K__ or is it H____? Doctor: K__. Gradually we can switch you back to here. Once those intense periods are done, the whatever you know close monitoring is done, then I would switch you back to coming here and getting the medication dispensed. Patient: Does is require an IV or anything like that? Doctor: It will. They’ll probably start an IV just to have it for blood draws. Family Member: But then that means they won’t prick you every time for the blood draw. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So I stay all day downtown or midtown? Family Member: And why are they, why do they, that’s interesting. Doctor: Well because they want to see how the levels of the drug, how long it takes for it to clear and things like that. So frankly along with the Xtandi there are not – this is sort of the first study of combining it with either Xtandi or Zytega and you know the single agent studies they kind of have they know what to expect. Family Member: Yeah.

Family Member: They gave me this application to fill out. Doctor: - let me know and we can work from this. Okay. But this was inappropriate anyway the way they confronted you like that. Family Member: Yeah, because it was harsh. Had we been a little bit older or fearful or… Doctor: Yeah, I know. Family Member: - not able to speak to ourselves we would have given - Doctor: Right, no, I agree with you.
FAM Sometimes people come in here and fall for that and they’re gonna give them part of their rent money and that’s what they to live. You never know. No, I agree. Family Member: But what I appreciate right now is that you’re listening to us. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Because even outside of his care, you want to be treated humanely. Doctor: Absolutely. Family Member: Or we’ll stay at home and he needs this place. Doctor: I would agree. Who doesn’t need a roof over the heads first of all?

Patient: When I was in the hospital checking every day - Doctor: Today your creatinine is one point zero. And your liver tests are all normal. Your PSA is pending; it looks like – Patient: They didn’t know. Doctor: It just hasn’t resulted yet. Family Member: Uh, the last reading when we were here on the twelfth of November, the reading was seventeen for PSA. Did that corrected? Doctor: Seventeen. Family Member: And the scale - is that improving or not or - Patient: Thirty-eight point six or thirty-eight. Family Member: I don’t know Doctor: It was forty-eight in July. Patient: Right. Doctor: And when I saw him on November seventh he had been on the pills for two weeks.

Patient: Right. Doctor: When you walk, how can you walk otherwise? Patient: Exactly. Doctor: And, you know, so that is a critical area that we may need to Patient: Okay. Doctor: do radiation to sort of help control it while we are planning for all of this other stuff. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So, that’s our plan. So, going forward, you’re going to have to see me much more frequently than before. Patient: That’s fine. I like you. I would not mind seeing you more frequently. Doctor: Thank goodness.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Uh, the – we always ask about pain, you know. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So, because pain does mean -- pain means we gotta do something now. Family Member: I get it. Doctor: Most people don’t have pain. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay? But people in the old days, maybe your father, you think about it, you know, um, that was pain that you remember. Okay? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Uh. But because of our better therapies, men have less pain. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: He’s got a lot of disease in his bone that there may be that they can’t sense pain. Family Member: Okay. Alright. Yeah. Alright.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: The PSA tells me it’s either this time or three months from now that we’re likely to see a change. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. But that’s what we’ve learned about Enzalutamide; don’t give up the ship until it’s clearly different. Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: Okay? Because these drugs could be providing a dampening effect Patient: Yeah, I know that. Yeah, Yeah. Doctor: So. Um. You know, my sense is that it is research because we’ve got a new drug added to it. You know, looking forward to having the conversation about what options might be still important. Um. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: Um. Um. (Pause5sec) Patient: So, why don’t we try to, to, to have the blood taken and, and, see if, if what that brings back, but maybe a a - in lieu of that possibly being negative, um, look at the other clinical trial. Doctor: So, I’ll go print out, uh, do you want me to just not print out the chemo one?

Family Member: To the study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That’s right. See? You’re everywhere. You’re taking trips you don’t even know you’re taking trips. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Patient: I’m tiring myself out. Family Member: a problem that we’re going out of town? Doctor: When are you going? Family Member: Saturday. Doctor: No. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: No. We won’t, I mean, with the holidays, you know, nothing happens. It’s almost like a, not a for sure. Next week it’s a shutdown, but a lot of places are still not functional- Family Member: Mm Hmm.

Patient: Right. Doctor: And, then, you could move into that study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you are AR-V7 negative and, uh, phase one study is of more interest to you, we can say, “Okay, you’re gonna stop as of this date the, the current study.” Patient: Right-- the drugs Doctor: And then we could reserve the slot for the new trial. Patient: Okay. Okay. That works. Doctor: Questions? Family Member: I do, I think that, uh, one of the, I guess, questions that came up in my mind was the signs of the cancer development in the adrenal is it consistent that it would be prostate cancer or we just don’t even know Doctor: Yeah. I mean, the assumption is that it is prostate cancer. Why give him a second cancer? Uh. So, that’s the assumption. You know, the adrenal gland can have benign tumors in it. Okay? Um. You know, if prostate cancer went in there, that would be a possible reason why it would bleed. Um. Sometimes the adrenal gland just doesn’t get a good blood supply, and it does bleed. Or, if you’re under stress, or like today with your blood pressure shooting through the roof, but your scans were yesterday. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh. It’s pretty nonspecific. Your aspirin puts you at a higher risk for like various

Family Member: Six. Doctor: So it was forty-six, forty-three, forty-nine. So that’s almost the same number to me, maybe a little bit elevated from the last time. And then uh the bone scan we did looks pretty much the same. There’s really nothing new. Uh they’re seeing this bone spot they saw before, looks about the same. Uh they thought they saw a spot on the left side of your sternum. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Well that’s been there for- Doctor: Yeah. So that, that really, they don’t really see anything new. So the only thing that’s changed is you have a couple of lymph nodes in the abdomen, pelvis that are, got a little bit bigger. Patient: Oh they have gotten? Doctor: Yeah. So uh so they looked along the aorta which is the main focus for down the body. Patient: Okay. Doctor: There’s lymph nodes all along there. So at different places uh- Patient: Are there new ones or it’s the same ones that are just enlarged? I mean- Doctor: It looks like the same ones have enlarged a bit. Patient: So what, so what does that tell us? Doctor: Well, it’s confusing because some are actually smaller. Uh up in the chest. So one for instance was point nine centimeters. Now it’s point six. And one was uh, uh. That’s actually a little bigger. Uh but the ones in the abdomen and lower down have all gotten bigger. So for the most part by a few millimeters.

Family Member: Do you have the results of today’s draw, blood draw? Doctor: I was told that he did not have blood drawn. Did he have it? Family Member: Yeah. Oh, yeah. Doctor: Yeah. No. I don’t, then. I’ll, uh, check. I’ll bring you the results. I don’t think I have a PSA back. Family Member: Oh. Right. Doctor: But, uh- Patient: So what, what involves, getting a shot every month or so? Doctor: Every six weeks, if you go on it. Patient: Every six weeks? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Hum. Well, what happens if I wanted to go to England and get it or Germany? Doctor: You’re a free man. You can go any time.

Patient: Oh, yeah. I’ll give you a heads up. You don’t have to worry about it. Patient: You don’t have to fix all that. That ain’t our best. Family Member: Who makes the appointment for it? Doctor: You got to do it. So when you walk out, right where you checked in, they will give you the times that’s convenient to both of you. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: They will scan and go when you’re done. Patient: We can’t go in the waiting room. We’ve still got a video to shoot. Doctor: Yeah. We’ve got a video to shoot. Yeah. (Laughter) Doctor: Oh, they’re ready for you, for your next take. I’ll take my paper now. Patient: I’ll see you later.

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If there’s another increase by fifty percent of then Patient: Okay. What’s the timeframe for the observation? Are we talking like a six month period of observations or what you’re saying that if I for whatever was to receive the observation does that one day receive the observation that would just remain until I hit the forty-two which could be like it could be a year? Doctor: So that’s, so that’s where the Patient: Okay. Doctor: You raise a very good question. Then if you go with the observation group and the PSA would still rise Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: and twelve months later your PSA is stabilizes Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Um, hum. And that is Doctor: In your case, if I would have to guess with your PSA track record –
